text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 11.51.2, Large Business and International Communications, LB&I Source Publishing Standards.
Changed name of IRM from LB&I Intranet Publishing Standards to LB&I Source Publishing Standards and changed references accordingly throughout the IRM.
Standards and changed references accordingly throughout the IRM. (
) IRM
: Changed the policy owner of this IRM to LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy and Governance office in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration organization. (
) IRM
: Adjustments made to the responsibilities for the LB&I Web & User Experience and Content Editors.
This IRM supersedes IRM 11.51.2 dated October 07, 2019.
LB&I Web Content Editors
Table of Contents
Source Publishing Standards 11.51.2
Source Publishing Standards

) Purpose: The LB&I Web & User Experience Team has developed a set Publishing and Content Standards to ensure a consistent look and feel Scope and throughout the LB&I Source. These standards must be adhered to, to a user experience that facilitates the primary goal of information well as the IRS Source policy of presenting information in a manner. (
) Audience: LB&I personnel trained and permissioned as Content Owners, Content Editors and subject matter experts (SMEs) on the LB&I Source. (
) Policy Owner: LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy and Governance in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration (
) Program Owner: LB&I Director of Communications. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The stakeholders for the program are the users LB&I Source. This population consists of all LB&I employees, in addition IRS employees that use content on the LB&I Source. (
) Program Goals: The goal of the program is to ensure consistency of throughout LB&I Source, consistency of content presentation with the IRS Source vision, and in compliance with IRM
, Content Policies and Standards for Intranet Sites. (
) IRS Source vs. LB&I Source: The LB&I Source migrated to the IRS platform as part of the Servicewide vision of moving all intranet content to IRS Source as the replacement of the IRWeb. (

) Content Dispersal: The IRS vision for intranet content, requires splitting content that was formerly housed in singular intranet sites. This vision is lated by IRS Communications & Liaison (C&L); and consists of content in of three platforms: • IRS Source (and business unit sub-sites) – information on operations, organization, and news items • Servicewide Knowledge Library – information on “how to do your for knowledge retention and sharing • Collaborative Shar
oint sites – restricted permission sites, for documents and information, and small-team collaborative efforts (
) Authority for intra-site consistency is derived from IRM
, Intranet and Servers Must Be Registered. (

) The LB&I Web & User Experience Team is responsible for: • Ensuring that the content published on the LB&I Source is not the primary source of instructions to staff. Note: The IRM is the primary, official source of instructions to • Providing overall standards for the LB&I Source • Managing the global navigation and content regions • Managing the overall LB&I Source design and governance • Providing Content Editors the tools and subject matter technical necessary to perform their duties No.
E (
) Internal Revenue Manual marked with a #

Purpose: The LB&I Web & User Experience Team has developed a set of Publishing and Content Standards to ensure a consistent look and feel throughout the LB&I Source. These standards must be adhered to, to provide a user experience that facilitates the primary goal of information availability, as well as the IRS Source policy of presenting information in a content
based manner.
Audience: LB&I personnel trained and permissioned as Content Owners, Content Editors and subject matter experts (SMEs) on the LB&I Source.
Policy Owner: LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy and Governance office in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration organization.

IRS Source (and business unit sub-sites) – information on day-to-day operations, organization, and news items Servicewide Knowledge Library – information on “how to do your job”, for knowledge retention and sharing Collaborative Shar
oint sites – restricted permission sites, for documents and information, and small-team collaborative efforts
Authority for intra-site consistency is derived from IRM 11.1.4.4, Intranet Sites and Servers Must Be Registered.

Large Business and International • Managing root-level content and content-based landing pages • Managing the Headquarters level organization-based pages • Managing LB&I Source news items • Instructing the LB&I Source Content Editor training (ITM #

) or equivalent • Being the focal point of contact for web technology in LB&I • Being the focal point of contact for web server applications in LB&I • Performing Sharepoint maintenance and content reviews necessary • Conducting annual review of Sharepoint permissions to ensure and accuracy of its members (

) Content Owners are responsible for: • Identifying candidates for the role of Content Editor and SME, and providing those candidates with the time and resources necessary to complete the required training • Ensuring there is an established review and approval process for all content to be published to the LB&I Source • Ensuring that the review process includes Section

compliance checks, Electronic Freedom of Information Act (E-FOIA) and Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act (SBREFA) and any other applicable regulations • Ensuring LB&I Source content under their purview is still valid and contains only current information • Ensuring that Content Editors and SMEs are properly trained and equipped to perform their duties • Ensuring that Content Editors and SMEs are provided adequate time and support to manage their assigned content (

) Content Editors/SMEs are responsible for: • Ensuring that the content published on the LB&I Source is not the primary source of instructions to staff. Note: The IRM is the primary, official source of instructions to staff. • Ensuring the content on their pages is current and up-to-date • Updating and maintaining Sharepoint metadata for which they are assigned • Coordinating with the LB&I Web & User Experience Team regarding problems or metadata changes they may need • Ensuring that content posted on their pages is Section

• Coordinating release of information on IRS.gov that is subject to or SBREFA • Removing any content that is obsolete or out-of-date • Correct spelling and grammar of content submitted for publishing • Identifying when/if they expect to be unable to serve in the SME capacity • Ensuring the established review and approval process is followed submitting updates • Successfully completing the LB&I Source Content Editor training #

) and any required prerequisites or post-requisites • Completing any refresher or follow-up training related to the LB&I Source Content Editor training • Directing inquiries related to technical content to the appropriate channels

Source Publishing Standards 11.51.2

Adhering to the IRS Intranet Standards (1) Commonly used terms and acronyms are deﬁned below. Deﬁned Terms Term Deﬁnition Aircard A device that allows a broadband internet con- nection, typically via USB interface, without a wired (RJ-45 ethernet) or wireless (802.11 protocol). Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition CSS Cascading Style Sheets E-FOIA Electronic Freedom of Information Act HTML HyperText Markup Language PDF Portable Document Format SBREFA Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act SME Subject Matter Expert
The W
Schools website is a good resource for learning Hype
ext Language (HTML), Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), Jav
cript and other related topics. See https://www.w
schools.com/. Servicewide Standard Incorporation - Whenever applicable, the IRS standards outlined in IRM
should be adhered to, in order to consistency across the IRS Source platform for the IRS intranet. LB&I Source Consistency - Per IRM

, Intranet Sites and Servers Be Registered, the LB&I Source must maintain a consistent appearance. LB&I Web & User Experience Team provides a standard set of HTML and functions, which provide this consistency. Additionally, this IRM requires that the LB&I Office of Communications approve any LB&I site. Approval is at the discretion of the LB&I Web & User Experience and will be provided in writing, when granted. Proprietary Computer Code - Per IRM

, Proprietary Computer Must Be Approved Before Use, the use of proprietary computer code (to include open source code) is restricted to only those approved by IRS IT terprise Architecture. LB&I has obtained approval for the use of the

Proprietary Computer Code - Per IRM 11.1.4.13, Proprietary Computer Code Must Be Approved Before Use, the use of proprietary computer code (to include open source code) is restricted to only those approved by IRS IT En- terprise Architecture. LB&I has obtained approval for the use of the JQuery

Large Business and International and Bootstrap javascript libraries. No other proprietary computer code is to used on the LB&I Source, without written authorization from the LB&I Web & User Experience Team. (
) Custom-built Web Code - LB&I Web & User Experience Team must be submitted to the LB&I Web & User Experience Team for review and approval prior to implementation. (

) Included HTML Content – Methods of including external HTML, and other based code, must be approved by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team the IRS Cybersecurity office. Virtual inclusion of external content the security structure of the IRS Source and Shar

oint servers. An error in code loop could result in a perpetual burden on the web servers, and could cause them to crash, resulting in a denial of service for the entire IRS hosted on the physical server. (

) This sub-section provides the general guidelines and restrictions for content published to the LB&I Source. These guidelines and restrictions ensure ance with accessibility laws, privacy laws, as well as with the Servicewide standards. (

) Content on the LB&I Source will be maintained as long as it remains current, accurate and applicable. Content that no longer serves a business purpose be removed to ensure availability of storage space, as well as to eliminate confusion for users. (

) Content will be archived according to standard practice, and will not be tained on the web for “historical” purposes. Content that is required to be maintained for “historical” or other “archiving” purposes should be maintained using appropriate record retention methods by the content owner. (

) Content must also properly belong on the LB&I Source or have an exception from the LB&I Web & User Experience Team to temporarily house on the Source. Content with a temporary exception will be maintained for a period one year, after which time, it must receive another exception to remain on LB&I Source. Other proper platforms for content are the Servicewide Knowledge Management Virtual Library, and Shar
oint collaborative sites. (
) If content properly belongs in the IRS Source platform, and has a audience, the author/owner will coordinate with the LB&I Web & User ence Team to have it placed on the IRS Source. (
) If the content properly belongs in the Servicewide Knowledge Management Virtual Library or a collaborative Shar
oint site, the author/owner will nate with the HCO SKM team or the LB&I Shar
oint Project Office to have placed in the appropriate platform. (
) Web pages will be designed to inherently support accessibility. Section
U.S.C.
d – commonly referred to as “Section

of the Rehabilitation requires all Federal agencies to make their electronic and information ogy accessible to people with disabilities. To comply with this requirement, all visual content must provide a text-only format, available to screen reader nology. Additionally, the following considerations are to be followed: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
E
Large Business and International Communications
Source Publishing Standards 11.51.2
Standards

• Images, pictures, and diagrams should provide alternative text where appropriate • Images that only serve a visual function, and could inhibit the of a webpage if “ﬁller” alternative text is provided, should be given a NULL alt text value (alt=””) • Red text should be avoided, except for the common practice of input validation • Underlined text should never be used, as it commonly denotes text • Italicized text should only be used for quoted material • Emphasis may be provided using boldface text (<strong> HTML tag), but it should be used sparingly, and in a manner that does not from the readability of the page (

) Files uploaded, and made available for users to download via hyperlink, be thoroughly checked for accessibility. While all parties involved are sible for the accessibility of documents published to the web, Content providers/contributors/authors retain the primary responsibility for correcting any accessibility shortfalls. The built-in accessibility tools in the Microsoft Suite and Adobe Acrobat provide adequate functionality for ensuring Section

compliance. Documents may be submitted to the IRS Alternative Media Center for review prior to publishing to LB&I Source, or alternatively, the Web & User Experience Team can assist with some accessibility concerns. (

) In general, the LB&I Source must be presented in an accessible format. sibility of web content is not a “compliant” or “non-compliant” issue, but a sliding scale, by which content can have varying degrees of compliance. foremost goal is to provide a web experience to all users, which is as nearly identical as practical. Resources for accessibility include: • The IRS Alternative Media Center (AMC) Office • The IRS Information Resources Accessibility Program (IRAP) Office • IRS Web Services • Web Resources on Section
Compliance (

) Content published on the LB&I Source must properly reﬂect the professional nature of the Internal Revenue Service and the Large Business & Division. No content should be published that reﬂects poorly upon LB&I or IRS. (

) All content published to the LB&I Source must have a valid business and serve the overall goals of LB&I. Content should help users take a action, learn or reinforce a skill, or ﬁnd content related to their official duties. (

) The IRS’s policy on limited personal use extends not only to users of the Source, but also to Content Editors regarding content publishing. LB&I pages must not link to content that is inappropriate or prohibited by the IRS limited personal use policy. (

) Content should not be duplicated on the LB&I Source. This means that if content is available elsewhere on the IRS network, Content Editors should to the relevant content. Additionally, if content is published on the internet (IRS.gov), LB&I Source pages should link to that content, rather generate duplicate information. These rules are in addition to E-FOIA and SBREFA considerations. Internal Revenue Manual

compliance. Documents may be submitted to the IRS Alternative Media Center for review prior to publishing to LB&I Source, or alternatively, the LB&I Web & User Experience Team can assist with some accessibility concerns. In general, the LB&I Source must be presented in an accessible format. Acces-

Content should not be duplicated on the LB&I Source. This means that if content is available elsewhere on the IRS network, Content Editors should link to the relevant content. Additionally, if content is published on the public-facing internet (IRS.gov), LB&I Source pages should link to that content, rather than generate duplicate information. These rules are in addition to E-FOIA and
Large Business and International (

) Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) information should never be published to LB&I Source. SBU content includes (but is not limited to) tax and personnel Restrictions (privacy) information. For example; publishing speciﬁc tax cases even if removing the taxpayer identifying information is inappropriate and unaccept- able. (

) If Official Use Only (OUO) information is published on the LB&I Source it be clearly identiﬁable as OUO information by indicating the # sign where the OUO information is located, along with other identifying information at the of the webpage, to indicate that it contains OUO information. HTML coding should be used to remove this information from the printable webpage so that it cannot be printed and inadvertently provided to outside entities. To set content to be non-printable, add the class attribute “no print” to the container element. (

) Source and Attribution is an acceptable manner of publishing third-party mation. However, care must be used to ensure that the source of the information is identiﬁed and the information is not embellished with from the tax or personnel record. Example: You can publish the success of an indictment or conviction using wording like: In the Newark Star Ledger dated February

it reported that... “the United States Attorney received an indictment against John Q. Public for tax evasion as the result of his involvement an abusive tax scheme. ” The important thing to remember is to include the source and attribute the formation to the source, so as not to accidentally give the impression that IRS or LB&I are the source. When possible, link to the original source. (
) Every page on the LB&I Source should have a clear purpose and audience. appropriate, consider a brief introductory sentence or paragraph to describe Web Publishing the purpose of the page. (

) The excessive use of images and graphics has a negative impact on readability and performance (speed of page loading). Use images sparingly and only when the image adds value to the content it accompanies or a business goal. Further information regarding accessibility standards can found in IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content. Further information regarding graphics can be found in IRM
, Image and Graphic ﬁcations. (

) All webpages must be checked for spelling and grammatical errors as well ensuring that links are valid, before they are published. Do not solely rely the software’s spell check function. Proofread all content for readability and correct errors that may have been missed by the spell checker. (
) Writing for the web is very different from writing for a hardcopy print Studies have shown that reading from computer screens is
percent for the LB&I and creates more eyestrain than reading from hardcopy. (
) Federal Plain Language Guidelines should be used to convey information cinctly and clearly to readers. The Servicewide training ITM Course

For example; publishing speciﬁc tax cases even if removing the taxpayer identifying information is inappropriate and unaccept- able. (

) If Official Use Only (OUO) information is published on the LB&I Source it must be clearly identiﬁable as OUO information by indicating the # sign where the OUO information is located, along with other identifying information at the top of the webpage, to indicate that it contains OUO information. HTML coding should be used to remove this information from the printable webpage proﬁle, so that it cannot be printed and inadvertently provided to outside entities. To set content to be non-printable, add the class attribute “no print” to the container element. (

) Source and Attribution is an acceptable manner of publishing third-party infor- mation. However, care must be used to ensure that the source of the information is identiﬁed and the information is not embellished with information from the tax or personnel record.
You can publish the success of an indictment or conviction using wording like: In the Newark Star Ledger dated February
it was reported that... “the United States Attorney received an indictment against John Q. Public for tax evasion as the result of his involvement in an abusive tax scheme. ”

The important thing to remember is to include the source and attribute the in- formation to the source, so as not to accidentally give the impression that the IRS or LB&I are the source. When possible, link to the original source. (
) Every page on the LB&I Source should have a clear purpose and audience. appropriate, consider a brief introductory sentence or paragraph to describe the purpose of the page. (

) The excessive use of images and graphics has a negative impact on website readability and performance (speed of page loading). Use images sparingly and only when the image adds value to the content it accompanies or a business goal. Further information regarding accessibility standards can be found in IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content. Further information regarding graphics can be found in IRM
, Image and Graphic ﬁcations. (

) All webpages must be checked for spelling and grammatical errors as well as ensuring that links are valid, before they are published. Do not solely rely the software’s spell check function. Proofread all content for readability and correct errors that may have been missed by the spell checker. (
) Writing for the web is very different from writing for a hardcopy print medium. Studies have shown that reading from computer screens is
percent slower and creates more eyestrain than reading from hardcopy. (
) Federal Plain Language Guidelines should be used to convey information cinctly and clearly to readers. The Servicewide training ITM Course

Source Publishing Standards 11.51.2
“Writing for the Web” is a good resource for content developers, and ITM Course
“Write This Way!” is a good resource for general grammar English language conventions. (

) It is important to identify your target audience and understand their needs. Remember LB&I employees, managers, and executives are very busy and Your Intended need to access speciﬁc information on your webpages quickly and • Be an advocate for your audience. What do they want to know? do you need to tell them? Is it all there? Did you anticipate their questions? Did you lead them to pertinent related materials? • Understand your audience’s connectivity limitations. Many users are accessing your webpages through Employee Remote Access Project (ERAP) with slow connection speeds. This fact should always be a part of your decision of what to put on your webpages. • Use words and terminology appropriate to your intended audience. What words would your audience use? • Clearly explain all new or non-standard terms. When you introduce or unfamiliar acronyms, use the acronym and then, in parentheses, out the name or expression. Do not assume that the audience is with the term from another page of content. (

) Clearly state the purpose of the page in the ﬁrst paragraph. Introduce your topic at the start of your page and progress logically to the conclusion. Ambiguity Following this approach will help users identify if they are on the correct It can also help the search engine ﬁnd the correct page, based upon the content. • What does the audience need to know about the subject? • What should the audience do after they read the page? Make sure desired action is clearly stated and supported by the content. • Link users to related webpages and resources when appropriate. (

) Brevity is key. People are uncomfortable reading content on the computer screen. Seventy-nine percent of web readers scan. As a guideline, try to Content about half the words you would use in print publishing. • Use the inverted pyramid style of writing; put the most important mation at the top. • Web writing should be shorter than writing for hardcopy. Remove all necessary words. Documents intended for online reading should be over

words long. • Break up long pieces into short segments. Let your audience choose how much they want to read. • Use headers and sub-headers, so people can go right to the they want. Use standard HTML header tags to facilitate “scanning” screen readers. • Layer information by writing short introductory paragraphs that link to more in-depth information. • Organize information logically for the intended audience. • Limit yourself to one main idea per paragraph. (06-10-2016) Organize Content Efficiently

Use the inverted pyramid style of writing; put the most important infor- mation at the top. Web writing should be shorter than writing for hardcopy. Remove all necessary words. Documents intended for online reading should be over

words long. Break up long pieces into short segments. Let your audience choose how much they want to read. Use headers and sub-headers, so people can go right to the sections they want. Use standard HTML header tags to facilitate “scanning” screen readers. Layer information by writing short introductory paragraphs that link to more in-depth information. Organize information logically for the intended audience. Limit yourself to one main idea per paragraph.
Large Business and International (
) Spelling, grammar, punctuation and invalid link errors signiﬁcantly detract the professional nature of LB&I content. Review all content to make sure errors are avoided. (
) In addition to proper spelling, grammar, and punctuation, content should be written using the AP Style and the IRS Style Guide. (

) This subsection provides guidance on the standard design elements used throughout the LB&I Source. Most of these design elements are applied Design through the use of the global CSS applied to the IRS Source site These style choices are made by IRS C&L and should not be Using the built-in headings and styles from the IRS Source platform should always be used. This subsection provides guidance in the event an is granted by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team, and content has to manually styled. (
) Content Editors and SMEs should not use coding practices to circumvent IRS Source styles, as it is designed to provide the consistent appearance required by IRM
Using the built-in styles means that all content across the IRS Source platform will update when the global styles are by IRS C&L. (

) These standards are provided so that Content Editors can conﬁrm their Source content conforms to the standards, and request assistance if they encounter difficulty. Additionally, some of the standards cannot be invoked through the global styles, and this subsection provides guidance on ing these elements. (
) Due to the use of the IRS Source platform on Shar

oint, organizations LB&I will no longer have “landing pages” or “homepages”. The only Page Filenames pages used will be to provide navigation across the LB&I Source, to residing in the various Sharepoint lists. These “landing” pages will be tained by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team. (

) The standard background color for LB&I webpages is white, with a black font. LB&I Source pages must maintain the standard color scheme used Colors IRS Source. In addition, the standard colors from the “One IRS Design Standards” are preferred. The following color codes identify this schema: Description R G B Hex Code IRS Blue Primary

In order to properly use the headings, and ensure 508-compliance, use standard HTML heading style tags to deﬁne section and sub-section titles. Do
11.51 Large Business and International Communications
not use font style settings to format headings or mimic their appearance. The predeﬁned heading formats that may be used are:

The main page heading is applied through the [Title] ﬁeld of the content in the IRS Source platform. This is automatically applied to page, in large red font at the top of the page. Content titles and page headings should be short — normally no more than
words, and limited to
characters. Page sub-headings and document headings should use the
<h
> style option. These headings can generally be longer than headers but should still be kept short. Section headings should use the Heading
<h
> style option. are used to separate content in a logical fashion, and group content based upon topic. Sub-section headings should use the Heading
<h

> style option. These headings should be rarely used. Too much content on a single page can clutter the page and make ﬁnding information difficult. As a result, content should be spread across several pages, in a logical structure, that takes advantage of the inherent nature of hyperlinks across webpages. For this reason, Heading
will typically not be
Note: Using bold to circumvent heading styles is prohibited, as it does not to the Section 508 standards.
to the Section

standards. Italics: Italics should only be used for quoted material. When long sections of text are quoted, they should be indented to identify a blockquote. Other than quotations, italics should not be used, as it can cause eyestrain, and detract from the readability of the text. Underline: Underlined text should never be used on the LB&I Source, as it is reserved for automatic (default) styling of textual hyperlinks. The improper of underlining can cause user confusion, and the mistaken appearance that broken hyperlinks exist on the page. Highlighted Text: Highlighted text should never be used on the LB&I Source, as it can cause signiﬁcant eyestrain for sighted users, and is ignored by most screen-reading technology. Additionally, highlighted text on a webpage will often not display as highlighted when printed on a black-and-white printer. Highlighted text may be used by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team to identify old and unclaimed content. Until the content owner can be and corrective action taken, highlighted information should be considered obsolete and not relied upon. Other Stylized Text: Other stylized text should be avoided, as most practices can cause eyestrain, and are often not
-compliant. Additionally, certain styles are reserved for speciﬁc use; such as red-colored text, which is used identifying required ﬁelds, input validation errors, and other system

The improper of underlining can cause user confusion, and the mistaken appearance that broken hyperlinks exist on the page. Publishing Standards
page (
) General information pages should be short and to the point — no more screens in height (as scrolling on an
x
resolution screen size). They should highlight current or important developments and provide links to related content. Content should be organized into additional pages, to webpage “clutter”. (

) When content must be on the same page, long pages of text should be into appropriate sections using the appropriate heading types, with links provided at the top of the page. “Back to the top” links should be at appropriate intervals to assist in page navigation. (

) The page title from a browser perspective is distinguished by the page (content title), in that it appears in the title bar of the browser window (it is visually displayed in the content area of the webpage). The title also as the label in bookmarks to the page, as the page header when the page printed, and in search results, lists, and statistics reports. A page title should properly reﬂect the page’s content, be concise, and meaningful to the audience. This may, or may not, be the same as the page heading. (
) The page title is contained within the <title> tag, which resides in the tag of the webpage. This is automatically duplicated from the [Title] of the content, which also becomes the page heading <h
> and placed into the HTML code for the page. Manually changing the <title> is no longer in the IRS Source platform. (
) As a general rule, all LB&I Source content should be in webpage format. Source runs on the IRS Source platform on a Shar

oint server, which the server-side function of Active Server Pages. In the instance that ﬁle downloads must be used, the ﬁles will be stored in a document library, and ﬁles provided via a link on relevant content pages. This ensures that users provided contextual explanations of the documents, in line with the links to document download. (

) Every effort must be made to provide a webpage version of content as opposed to a ﬁle for download, to ensure a consistent user experience the LB&I Source. This means SMEs and Content Owners must create a webpage, or text version of Microsoft Office or Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF) documents, unless there is a bonaﬁde reason for providing content in a downloadable form (for example, a document needed for with a taxpayer, or a proforma worksheet for data-entry). (

) Documents should not be uploaded simply to avoid having to create a webpage. HTML webpage content is preferred for the following reasons: • Webpages more efficient and use less bandwidth. • Webpages provide a more consistent user experience. • Webpages are more accessible to users with assistive software or devices (Section

compliant). • Webpages are much more highly ranked for search results due to better Search Engine Optimization (SEO). • Documents are not parsed for content and are ranked much lower in search results. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Source Publishing Standards 11.51.2

Large Business and International (

) The ultimate goal of the LB&I Source is to provide information to the user, as efficiently and correctly as possible. Every effort should be made to facilitate the user’s consumption of the information, rather than ease of development publication. (
) The LB&I Web & User Experience Team can provide further guidance on making webpages Section
compliant, beyond this IRM section. Files available for download (when a webpage is not created for the content) be sent to the Alternative Media Center for review, prior to publishing. (

) In general, do not publish a PDF document directly to the web (i.e. LB&I Source). PDF documents should only be published to the web, when there is valid purpose; for example, ﬁllable PDF documents or ﬁles for printing and offline use. Most PDF forms are official forms or publications of the IRS. In these instances, do not publish copies of official publications; instead, link to the forms repository version from your webpage. To have official documents published, contact IRS Publishing Services. (

) Do not publish official memoranda and other documents with official signa- tures. Instead create a webpage, mimicking the memoranda or document. In place of the signature line, the following will be placed to identify that an signed document exists elsewhere: /s/ [Signing Official’s [MM/DD/YYYY] Name] [Official’s Title] Date [Official’s Organization] (

) Publishing documents with an official signature compromises the security of the signature. Content Authors should provide the Microsoft Word (or other word processing program) format, that gives all of the same text as the document to the SME or Content Editor for publishing. This facilitates the webpage version of the document more quickly, using paste text. (

) Official memoranda signed by LB&I executives and management must be published by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team on the LB&I News Center under “Other Messages”. Content Editors and SMEs will link to this published document, as needed. Official ﬁeld guidance and directives are subject to SBREFA and E-FOIA regulations and should be published on IRS.gov by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team. (

) In general, do not publish any Microsoft Word (.doc, .docx) ﬁles to the web (i.e. LB&I Source). There are limited circumstances where these types of ﬁles need to be provided to users in the original format. Examples of the Word document exceptions are: • a pro-forma workpaper • a document template for ﬁeld personnel • a ﬁllable form in MS Word format (
) MS Excel spreadsheets (.xls, .xlsx) should also not be published to the (i.e. LB&I Source). Spreadsheets that only provide information to users in a Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The three primary image formats used for the web are: • .GIF (Graphic Interchange Format) • .JPG (Joint Photographic Experts Group) • .PNG (Portable Network Graphics) (

) Any images or graphics that are created in another format (for example, .BMP, and .SVG) must be converted to either .GIF, .JPG, or .PNG prior to lishing on a webpage. Note that when you convert an image or graphic, aspects such as color or fonts may be affected, depending upon the that it is converted to. Contact the LB&I Web & User Experience Team for sistance in converting images to an appropriate format, without loss of resolution. (
) Reduce large image ﬁles to a “webpage” or “screen” resolution (or “print” lution as needed) before publishing on the web. The Microsoft Office Manager program is suitable for this task. (
) Graphics Interchange Format (.GIF) If you are offered different “save” options for the .GIF format; save the graphics as “
a Non-Interlaced .GIF ﬁles”. Animated .GIF ﬁles will NOT be used on the LB&I Source. (

) Joint Photographic Experts Group (.JPG) If you are offered options for the .JPG format, experiment with different compression levels determine the best balance between image quality and ﬁle size. Due to bandwidth considerations, you should use the lowest resolution possible without degrading the image quality. (
) All non-text items, including images, must include an alternative text (’alt attribute. Most images should receive descriptive text regarding the image content. See IRM
, Accessibility of Web Content, for more tion. (
) Minimize any extraneous background space in an image by cropping it. will help focus attention on the subject of the photo and reduce the overall of the image. (

Large Business and International (

) IRS Media & Publishing Services has introduced updated Design Standards the behest of the IRS Commissioner to help guide divisions and Branding in the proper development of formal documents, publications, presentations and similar materials. The Standards set forth include rules for correct use official IRS logos, seals, graphic designs and color schemes in IRS and publications. (

) The Design Standards are intended to reinforce the concept of “One IRS” ensuring the IRS brand appears properly and consistently across all parts the Service. LB&I has adopted these Standards and developed visuals to ensure that its own brand identity meets Servicewide requirements. (
) Refer to IRM
, Publishing, Use of the Official IRS Seal, IRS Logo, Program Logos and Internal Logos, and Document
, One look. One voice. One IRS., for more details and examples of how IRS Design are applied. (

) The IRS seal and Department of Treasury seal are used to represent the and Treasury in certain formal communications. In general, seals are used Seals on IRS letterhead stationary, official communications to the public from the Office of the Commissioner, other official and ceremonial documents and materials, and building signage. (

) The IRS and Treasury seals are not interchangeable with the IRS logo because they have historical signiﬁcance and are not easily distinguishable from other federal agency seals. Seals must be used in accordance with
, Official IRS Seal. (

) The official IRS logo is a graphic image consisting of the IRS eagle placed above or to the left of the acronym “IRS”. The IRS Logo must appear on all published and electronic products, with the exception of internal forms, and IRS letterhead. The IRS logo may be scaled to suit the needs of applications but may not be modiﬁed or changed in any other manner, when applied using the IRS “Wayﬁnding” system. (

) The IRS logo color may be black or IRS Blue on white, or White on IRS The IRS logo should always appear separate from any other images or elements of a page. No other content should touch or otherwise cover any of the IRS logo. (
) IRS Blue is PMS
C / HEX #
A
/ RGB
Black logos and blue logos must appear on white background. White logos may appear on IRS Blue background. (
) Contact the LB&I Office of Communications with questions about proper the IRS logo. (

) Many IRS divisions and departments are using homegrown logos and images to “brand” themselves visually. Because these logos and images inconsistent from one division and department to another, the overall IRS Wayﬁnding brand is weakened, possibly appearing disjointed and confusing to IRS taxpayers, employees and stakeholders. (
) To promote consistent branding and visual identity across the Service, Publishing Services has created a visual organizing framework called the Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
E Any line marked with
Large Business and International Communications
To promote consistent branding and visual identity across the Service, Media & Publishing Services has created a visual organizing framework called the IRS

Publishing Standards
page Wayﬁnding System. This system offers IRS offices a consistent, effective means of identifying and distinguishing themselves, ending the need for homegrown logos. (

) The wayﬁnding system incorporates names of operating divisions and ments in conjunction with the IRS logo. It reinforces the One IRS concept, while at the same time clearly identifying where various communications originate. (

) The wayﬁnding system also assigns standardized color palettes to IRS operating divisions and departments. Together with the department name, these assigned colors can help identify the source of published materials. Document
, IRS Design Standards & Guidelines, for examples of how wayﬁnding logos and colors may be used in IRS publications and (
) LB&I is fully embracing the IRS Wayﬁnding System. The LB&I Wayﬁnding may appear as blue-on-white, black-on-white, and white-on-blue. (

) LB&I organizations and departments are being asked to stop using “homegrown” department logos and graphics and transition to the System. LB&I department-speciﬁc wayﬁnding graphics can be requested the LB&I Web & User Experience Team. (

) This subsection provides guidance to ensure that content on the LB&I meets all applicable laws, including accessibility, privacy, and copyright. With Laws Content found to be non-compliant will be removed by the LB&I Web & Experience Team. (

) All federal agencies are required by law to make their websites accessible people with disabilities. Content providers are responsible for ensuring that content they submit for publishing is compliant with the accessibility of Section
) LB&I Source standard templates have been designed to ensure that all accessibility requirements are met. Do not alter these templates; doing so alter their accessibility. (
) Additional resources for accessibility can be found at: • Information Resources Accessibility Program website • Alternative Media Center website (

) LB&I is committed to protecting the privacy of our employees in both and paper records. Every webpage on IRS Source has a link to the Privacy Statement. LB&I program area sites should not create their own privacy page. (

) Employees may not publish to an IRS Source site any copyrighted material without license or written permission of the copyright owner. If there is any reason to believe that text, images, or other materials may belong to else, do not copy or otherwise use it without ﬁrst obtaining written (
) Internal Revenue Manual

) The wayﬁnding system incorporates names of operating divisions and depart- ments in conjunction with the IRS logo. It reinforces the One IRS concept, while at the same time clearly identifying where various communications originate. (

) The wayﬁnding system also assigns standardized color palettes to IRS operating divisions and departments. Together with the department name, these assigned colors can help identify the source of published materials. Document

LB&I is fully embracing the IRS Wayﬁnding System. The LB&I Wayﬁnding logo may appear as blue-on-white, black-on-white, and white-on-blue.
Large Business and International (

) If permission to use copyrighted material has been obtained, its use on the LB&I Source is still subject to approval by the LB&I Web & User Experience Team and LB&I Office of Communications Manager. A copy of the written thorization to use the copyrighted material will be required for approval. For additional information about this policy, refer to IRM
, Publishing Systems and Programs. (

) Graphics used on the LB&I Source site should be in the public domain. If purchases graphics for the website, and the purchase agreement speciﬁes of LB&I the vendor retains the copyright, then it should be noted on the page and in the text box (alt tag). A copy of the purchase agreement must be provided the LB&I Web & User Experience Team for record retention. Any graphics purchased are the property of the IRS as an organization, and any purchase agreement must reﬂect this. (

) If LB&I publishes written materials reprinted from outside sources, the owner must have written authorization from the holder of the copyright to publish the materials on LB&I Source and the copyright must be noted on page of the material. A copy of the written authorization must be provided the LB&I Web & User Experience Team for record retention. (

) The requirement for written authorization does not include content that is in public domain, or falling under the Fair Use Doctrine; however, Content are responsible for ensuring content used without written permission legally falls within these bounds. (
) Photos and graphics developed by grantees or contractors for IRS become property of the IRS and, therefore, are in the public domain. (

) Photos of employees and other individuals may be published to the web, with the individual’s written consent. Content Editors and SMEs must retain copy of the consent, as long as the photo is published on LB&I Source (whether available through a webpage, or simply stored on the server). (
) Official forms are published in the Electronic Publishing Catalog. Do not lish copies of official documents that are available in the Electronic Catalog; link to them instead. (
) The Electronic Publishing Catalog Help Section provides instructions on properly linking to published products. Additional resources can be found at: • Electronic Publishing Catalog Help Page • IRM
, Overview of Publishing Authorities, Roles and ties, and Organizational Structure (

) Surveys can be a valuable tool for collecting information in order to improve processes. However, care should be taken to ensure that certain things are avoided when using surveys. • Before requesting responses to a survey, ensure that all union ments are met. • Check that the survey, or portions of it, has not recently been in some manner. • Do not request survey responses during the same period as the Employee Satisfaction Survey. ) In light of the above, the Program Planning Coordination & Analysis (PPCA) office of Technology and Program Solutions (TPS) has the responsibility for survey administration. All surveys should be coordinated through the PPCA office to ensure compliance with the Commissioner’s memoranda. (

) The LB&I Office of Communications and the LB&I Web & User Experience Team have sole authority over the LB&I Source architecture, navigation, and site pages (aka “landing pages”). These are used to assist users of LB&I Source in locating content, and must conform to the same principles as the IRS Source. (
) LB&I news articles on the IRS Source homepage, such as the “News from Business Units” (BUN) section, must be routed through the LB&I Office of Communications for editing and approval. (

) Once LB&I content for IRS Source content is approved by the LB&I Office of Communications, the communications analysts will coordinate with the requestor to provide the information to the LB&I Web & User Experience for publishing. (
) The LB&I Web & User Experience Team will continually evaluate the content the LB&I Source, and make changes to the navigation as appropriate to aid users in ﬁnding content. (
) A decision tree for where content should be curated can be found in Exhibit

The Servicewide presentation was created to explain the change in content phy and was not meant to be authoritative. The LB&I decision tree was created in this spirit, and in an attempt to provide more speciﬁc examples for LB&I content.
